{{Infobox football match |title=Johan Cruijff-schaal III |image= |event= |team1=[[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] |team1association= |team1score=0 |team2=[[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] |team2association= |team2score=2 |details= |date=16 August 1998 |stadium=[[Amsterdam Arena]] |city=[[Amsterdam]] |man_of_the_match1a= |man_of_the_match1atitle= |man_of_the_match1b= |man_of_the_match1btitle= |referee=[[Mario van der Ende]] |attendance=39,500 |weather= |previous=[[1997 Johan Cruijff Schaal|1997]] |next=[[1999 Johan Cruijff Schaal|1999]]}} The match for the '''[[Johan Cruijff Shield|Johan Cruijff-schaal]] III''' was held on 16 August 1998 between [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]], who had won both the [[1997–98 Eredivisie]] and the [[1997–98 KNVB Cup]], and [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]], who had finished as runners-up in the 1997–98 Eredivisie (and, coincidentally, also in the 1997–98 KNVB Cup). PSV won the match 2–0.{{Cite web|url=http://www.footballdatabase.eu/football.coupe.ajax-amsterdam.psv-eindhoven.81077.en.html|title=Football - Match Johan Cruijff Schaal : Ajax Amsterdam vs. PSV Eindhoven|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=FootballDatabase.eu|access-date=17 June 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.beijen.net/frank/wedst/1998/980816ap.htm|title=Ajax - PSV, Johan Cruijff Schaal III 1998|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Voetbalfocus|language=Dutch|access-date=17 June 2016}}{{Cite web|url=http://home.planet.nl/~rapo/psv/supercup/knvb.html|title=PSV in de Nederlandse Supercup|last=Posthouwer|first=Raymond|date=|website=|publisher=PSV Eindhoven Wedstrijdhistorie|language=Dutch|access-date=17 June 2016}} {{clear}} == Match == === Details === {{Football box |date={{Start date|1998|8|16|df=y}} |team1=[[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] |team2=[[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] |time= |score=0–2 |goals1= |report=http://www.footballdatabase.eu/football.coupe.ajax-amsterdam.psv-eindhoven.81077.en.html |goals2=[[Dmitri Khokhlov|Khokhlov]] {{goal|32}}

{{Football club infobox | clubname = AS Tamarii Punaruu | image = Tamarii_Punaruu.jpg | image_size = 200 | fullname = Association Sportive Tamarii Punaruu | nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Stade Punaruu]]
[[Puna'auia]], [[Tahiti]], [[French Polynesia]] | capacity = | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Tahiti Ligue 2]] | season = [[2017-18]] |position = 10th in [[2017-18 Tahiti Ligue 1|Ligue 1]]('''relegated''') }} '''Association Sportive Tamarii Punaruu''', is a [[football (soccer)|football]] club from [[Puna'auia]], [[Tahiti]]. They currently compete in the [[Tahiti Ligue 2]] the second tier of the football system in [[Tahiti]],[https://www.ftf.pf/ligue-2-2/], Fédération Tahitienne de Football after been relegated in the [[2017-18 Tahiti Ligue 1]]. They play their home games at Stade Punaruu. ==Achievements== *'''[[Tahiti Ligue 1]]: 1''' ::1969. *'''[[Tahiti Cup]]: 2''' ::1968, 1969. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://punaruu.com/ Official website] {{FrenchPolynesia-sport-stub}} {{Oceania-footyclub-stub}} [[Category:Tahitian football clubs]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = AMSOIL Arena | image = [[File:AMSOIL_Arena,_Duluth,_Minnesota_(23409979654).jpg|center|320px|AMSOIL Arena]] | location = 350 Harbor Drive
[[Duluth]], [[Minnesota]] 55802 | broke_ground = September 2008 | built = | opened = December 30, 2010 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Duluth Entertainment Convention Center | operator = Duluth Entertainment Convention Center | surface = 85' x 200' (Ice) | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]80 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|80000000|2010}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous]] (formerly [[HOK (firm)|HOK]] Sport)
SJA Architects | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = Mortenson/Thor[http://decc.org/amsoil-arena/arena-facts.html] | main_contractors = | commercial cleaner = | former_names = | seating_capacity = 6,726 (Hockey){{cite news |title=AMSOIL Arena|url=http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/amsoil-arena-s1513|accessdate=October 9, 2014}}
9,264 (Concerts){{cite web|last1=Gustafson|first1=C.|title=Amsoil Arena: Duluth's new hockey home|url=http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/content/amsoil-arena-duluths-new-hockey-home|website=Duluth News Tribune|accessdate=20 February 2017}} | record_attendance = 8,372 | tenants = [[Minnesota-Duluth Bulldogs men's ice hockey|UMD Bulldogs men's hockey]] ([[National Collegiate Hockey Conference|NCHC]]) (2010–present)
[[Minnesota-Duluth Bulldogs women's ice hockey|UMD Bulldogs women's hockey]] ([[WCHA]]) (2011–present) | website = {{URL|http://decc.org/venue/amsoil-arena/}} }} '''AMSOIL Arena''' is a multipurpose [[arena]] in [[Duluth]], [[Minnesota]], home to the [[UMD Bulldogs men's ice hockey|UMD Men's]] and [[UMD Bulldogs women's ice hockey|UMD Women's]] hockey teams. It opened in 2010, replacing the [[Duluth Entertainment Convention Center]] Arena on the waterfront near Duluth's landmark [[Aerial Lift Bridge]]. Naming rights for 20 years were purchased by [[AMSOIL]], a [[corporation]] based in [[Superior, Wisconsin]], for $6 million, one-third up front.{{Cite news |url=http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/content/6-million-its-amsoil-arena |title=For $6 million, it's Amsoil Arena |last=Kuchera |first=Steve |date=May 11, 2010 |newspaper=Duluth News Tribune |access-date=February 20, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Hanson|first1=Howie|title=Naming rights for new Duluth arena; UMD names new chancellor|url=http://www.startribune.com/naming-rights-for-new-duluth-arena-umd-names-new-chancellor/93423339/|website=Star Tribune|accessdate=20 February 2017}} The facility cost nearly $80 million; about half ($38 million) paid by the State of Minnesota through a 2008 bond bill, another 27% (about $21.6 million) by a voter-approved city food-and-beverage tax increase, 12% (about $9.6 million) by [[University of Minnesota-Duluth|UMD]], and the last 11% (about $8.8 million) by the DECC. Construction ran from September 2008 to December 2010, and included a 475-space parking garage with a [[skywalk]] connecting it to the arena.url=http://umdbulldogs.com/sports/2013/8/30/Amsoil-Arena.aspx?path=general The first event held at the arena was on December 30, 2010. UMD men's hockey team lost 0-5 to North Dakota before a crowd of 6,764, tied for the team's highest home attendance that season. In their first season in the arena, the UMD men's hockey team won the [[NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship]]. In 2012, the arena hosted the [[2012 NCAA Division I Women's Ice Hockey Tournament]], in which [[Minnesota Golden Gophers women's ice hockey|Minnesota]] beat [[Wisconsin Badgers women's ice hockey|Wisconsin]], 4-2. The arena's attendance record was set on June 20, 2018 during a President [[Donald Trump]] rally, which drew 8,372 people.{{cite news |last1=Slater |first1=Brady |title=Trump playful in Duluth |url=https://www.duluthnewstribune.com/news/government-and-politics/4463195-trump-playful-duluth |accessdate=21 June 2018 |publisher=Duluth News Tribune |date=20 June 2018}} The attendance record for a sporting event was set on October 17, 2015, when UMD men's hockey team defeated their rival, [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's hockey|Minnesota]], 3-0 in front 7,569 fans.{{cite web|title=Record GPA, Record Attendance Among UMD's 2015-2016 Athletic Highlights|url=http://umdbulldogs.com/news/2016/6/30/general-record-gpa-record-attendance-among-umds-2015-16-athletic-highlights.aspx?mobile=skip|website=The Official Site of the University of Minnesota-Duluth|date=July 12, 2016|accessdate=19 February 2017}} ==Comparison to DECC Arena== {| class="wikitable" align=center style="font-size: 95%; text-align:center;" ! Characteristic !!DECC Arena!!AMSOIL Arena |- ! Hockey seating | 5,100 || 6,726 |- ! Concessions | 28 || 35 + 6 portable |- ! Club space | 0 sq. ft. || 2000 sq. ft. |- ! Suites | 0 || 16 |- ! Leg room between rows | 31" || 34" lower, 33" upper |- ! Elevators | 1 || 3 |- ! Scoreboard | 10' x 12' || 15' x 20' |- ! Ice sheet | 85' x 190' || 85' x 200' |} ==Arena Usage== ===Hockey=== AMSOIL Arena is primarily used as a hockey arena home to the University of Minnesota-Duluth's men's and women's hockey teams. The arena hosted the [[2012 NCAA Division I Women's Ice Hockey Tournament]]. AMSOIL Arena hosted the 2017 Ice Breaker Tournament, held October 6-7th 2017. Four teams participated in the tournament. Michigan Tech defeated Union College 6-3 and University of Minnesota Duluth defeated University of Minnesota 4-3 in overtime in the tournament's first round. In the final round, University of Minnesota Duluth fell to tournament champion Michigan Tech 4-3, while in the consolation game the University of Minnesota beat Union College 2-0. Other hockey events include preseason practices for the [[National Hockey League]]'s [[Minnesota Wild]]-open to the public, [[Minnesota State High School League]] section 7A and 7AA tournament games, as well as a high-school all-star game. ===Basketball=== AMSOIL Arena hosted the [[Harlem Globetrotters]] in 2012, 2014, 2016, 2017 and 2018, for which [[Minnesota Lynx]]'s ([[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]]) court was brought up from [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. [[File:AMSOILArena,April12011.jpg|thumbnail|right|Globetrotters Basketball Game on April 1, 2011]] ===Events=== AMSOIL Arena has held many different types of events, from comedians [[Jeff Dunham]] and [[Jim Gaffigan]] to [[Cirque du Soleil]]. The local AAD Shrine holds its annual AAD Shrine Circus fundraiser at the arena each April.url=http://decc.org/event/71st-annual-aad-shrine-circus/ The arena also hosts concerts. The [[Duluth Superior Symphony Orchestra]] had the first non-sporting event held at the arena, "Cirque de la Symphonie on Ice", on December 31, 2010, a day after the facility opened. It can also be converted to host dinners and [[convention (meeting)|conventions]]. On June 20, 2018 President [[Donald Trump]] held a rally in the arena that saw a record breaking attendance of 8,372. {| class="wikitable" align=center style="font-size: 95%; text-align:center;" |+ Concerts |- ! [[Brandon Radcliff]] | The Miss Me More Tour | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} | |- |} ==Awards== In 2013, ''Stadium Journey'' rated AMSOIL Arena as the best stadium experience in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.stadiumjourney.com/news/01-06-2014/535/stadium-journey%E2%80%99s-top-100-stadium-experiences-of-2013/ |title=Stadium Journey's Top 100 Stadium Experiences of 2013 |last=Swaney |first=Paul |date=January 6, 2014 |publisher=Stadium Journey}} In 2014 and 2015, ''Stadium Journey'' rated AMSOIL Arena as the second best stadium experience in the United States and Canada, behind [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards]] home to [[Major League Baseball]]'s [[Baltimore Orioles]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.scout.com/stadium-journey/story/1681104-top-100-stadium-experiences-of-2014 |title=Stadium Journey's Top 100 Stadium Experiences of 2014 |last=Swaney |first=Paul |date=January 8, 2015 |publisher=Stadium Journey}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.scout.com/stadium-journey/story/1681339-top-100-stadium-experiences-of-2015 |title=Stadium Journey's Top 100 Stadium Experiences of 2015 |last=Swaney |first=Paul |date=January 7, 2016 |publisher=Stadium Journey}} AMSOIL Arena was ranked the best college hockey arena by ''Stadium Journey'' in 2014 and 2015.{{Cite news |url=http://www.scout.com/stadium-journey/story/1681079-college-hockey-arena-rankings |title=College Hockey Arena Rankings |last=Baker |first=Paul |date=April 13, 2014 |publisher=Stadium Journey}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.scout.com/stadium-journey/story/1681346-college-hockey-arena-rankings |title=College Hockey Arena Rankings |last=Swaney |first=Paul |date=March 24, 2015 |publisher=Stadium Journey}} The [[Wall Street Journal]] named AMSOIL Arena one of its 10 "Golden Zamboni" winners for its uniqueness among the nation's college hockey venues.https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704132204576136462675400454 ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the

[[Minnesota-Duluth Bulldogs women's ice hockey|UMD Bulldogs Women's Hockey]] | years = 2011-present | before = [[DECC Arena]] | after = Current }} {{succession box | title = Host of the [[National Collegiate women's ice hockey championship|NCAA Women's DI Ice Hockey Tournament]] | years = [[2012 NCAA National Collegiate Women's Ice Hockey Tournament|2012]] | before = [[Erie Insurance Arena]] | after = [[Ridder Arena]] }} {{s-end}} {{Minnesota–Duluth Bulldogs men's ice hockey navbox}} {{Minnesota–Duluth Bulldogs women's ice hockey navbox}} {{Western Collegiate Hockey Association women's navbox}} {{National Collegiate Hockey Conference}} {{Music venues of Minnesota}} {{coord|46|46|53|N|92|05|53|W|type:landmark_region:US-MN|display=title}} [[Category:College ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Minnesota]] [[Category:Convention centers in Minnesota]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Duluth, Minnesota]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Duluth, Minnesota]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Minnesota]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Minnesota]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:RichardPettyRoadrunner.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Richard Petty's Superbird at the Petty Museum]] '''Aero Warriors''' is a nickname for four [[Muscle car|muscle cars]], also called '''aero-cars''', developed specifically to race on the [[NASCAR]] circuit by [[Dodge]], [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]], [[Ford]] and [[Mercury (automobile)|Mercury]] for the 1969 and 1970 racing seasons. The cars were based on production stock cars but had additional aerodynamic features.
The first Aero Warrior was the 1969 [[Ford Torino Talladega]]. The [[Ford Torino|Torino]] already had a [[fastback]] design; the Talladega added a longer, slightly rounded front end. The second Aero Warrior was the 1969 [[Mercury Cyclone Spoiler II]]. The Cyclone was nearly identical to the Torino with the only major distinctions being the front grille and rear taillights. Another aero car is the [[Dodge Charger Daytona]], which had a more radical aerodynamic nose as well as a high-mounted wing at the rear. The final Aero Warrior was the 1970 [[Plymouth Superbird]] (based on the [[Plymouth Road Runner]]), which had the same aerodynamic additions as the Daytona. Because of their wings, the [[Mopar]] Aero Warriors are sometimes called the '''Winged Warriors'''.
Due to NASCAR [[Homologation (motorsport)|homologation]] rules a minimum number (500) of these cars had to be offered for sale to the public so there are approximately 3,000 of these cars in private ownership. The Aero Warriors were successful in winning many races, but NASCAR made rule changes that equalized the advantages in 1971. Plymouth made a Superbird prototype in 1971 but it did not go into production.
[[Category:Chrysler]] [[Category:NASCAR terminology]] [[Category:Nicknames in sports]]

page.title: Bahamas at the 2007 Pan American Games

revision.text:
{{Infobox country at games | NOC = BAH | NOCname = [[Bahamas Olympic Association]] | year = 2007 | date = 13–29 July 2007 | games = Pan American Games | location = [[2007 Pan American Games|Rio de Janeiro]] | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = [[Jeremy Knowles (swimmer)|Jeremy Knowles]] | officials = | gold = 2 | silver = 2 | bronze = 3 | rank = 15 | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | seealso = | website = }} The '''[[2007 Pan American Games|15th Pan American Games]]''' were held in [[Rio de Janeiro|Rio de Janeiro, Brazil]] from July 13 to July 29, 2007.
==Medals==
===[[Image:Gold medal america.svg|20px]] Gold=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Athletics pictogram.svg|event=Athletics}} *Men's 400 metres: [[Chris Brown (athlete)|Chris Brown]] *Men's 4x400 metres Relay: [[Andrae Williams]], [[Avard Moncur]], [[Michael Matheau]], and [[Chris Brown (athlete)|Chris Brown]]
===[[Image:Silver medal america.svg|20px]] Silver=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Athletics pictogram.svg|event=Athletics}} *Men's High Jump: [[Donald Thomas (athlete)|Donald Thomas]] *Women's 400 metres: [[Christine Amertil]]
===[[Image:Bronze medal (Americas).svg|20px]] Bronze=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Athletics pictogram.svg|event=Athletics}} *Women's 100 metres: [[Chandra Sturrup]] *Women's Javelin: [[Laverne Eve]]
{{Pan American Games medal title|year=2007|image = Swimming pictogram.svg|event=Swimming}} *Women's 4 × 100 m medley relay: [[Alana Dillette]], [[Alicia Lightbourne]], [[Arianna Vanderpool]], [[Nikia Deveaux]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=April 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} The '''Bank of England club''' is a nickname in English [[association football]] for a football club which has a strong financial backing. It was used to refer to [[Arsenal F.C.]] in the 1930s as well as in recent times for being the last of the [[Premier League]]'s [[Big Four (English football)|Big Four]] clubs to be owned primarily by English investors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13040475 |title=BBC Sport - US businessman Stan Kroenke agrees bid to buy Arsenal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2011-04-11 |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref>
==Origins and usage==
===Arsenal===
[[File:Arsenal Stadium Highbury east facade.jpg|thumb|[[Arsenal Stadium|Highbury's]] Art Deco east facade]]
The name "Bank of England club" or "Bank of England team" caught after the [[World football transfer record|record-breaking spending]] of Arsenal in the 1920s and 1930s. [[Bernard Joy]] recalled that people "sneered at the 'Bank of England' methods of team building" after the five-digit figure paid for [[David Jack]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Joy|first1=Bernard|title=Forward, Arsenal!|date=2009|publisher=GCR Books Limited|isbn=9780955921117|page=49|edition=illustrated, reprint|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=zxavt42c3t0C|language=en}}</ref> Arsenal continued to spend considerable sums on other players, including [[Alex James (footballer)|Alex James]], and, in 1938, broke the [[Progression of British football transfer fee record|English transfer record]] again with the purchase of [[Bryn Jones (footballer, born 1912)|Bryn Jones]].
Arsenal's new home in [[Arsenal Stadium|Highbury]] had provided them with considerable resources, such that, in 1935, they became the first club to earn over £100,000 from gate receipts.<ref>{{cite book|title=Terrace Heroes: The Life and Times of the 1930s Professional Footballer|author=Graham Kelly|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0714653594|year=2005|page=26}}</ref> Accompanied by £2,500 earned from match day programme sales and financial reserves of over £60,000, the "Bank of England club" moniker became regularly used to describe Arsenal.<ref name="sport" /> It was also used to refer to the perceived grandeur of Arsenal's surroundings after the 1930s construction of Highbury's [[Art Deco]] stands and [[terrazzo]] "Marbled Halls".<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/blighty/2011/04/takeover_arsenal |title=The takeover of Arsenal: The most English of football clubs goes American |work=The Economist |date=2011-04-12 |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref>
This lasted until the [[Second World War]], when Arsenal's Highbury stadium was requisitioned as an [[Air Raid Precautions]] post and was bombed. The cost of repairing Highbury and gaining no income from being able to play home [[Wartime League]] matches eliminated most of Arsenal's cash reserves, which meant that the "Bank of England club" descriptor gradually became less used and redundant.<ref name="sport">{{cite book|title=Terrace Heroes: The Life and Times of the 1930s Professional Footballer|author=Graham Kelly|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0714653594|year=2005|page=82}}</ref>
In 2011, when [[Stan Kroenke]] became the majority shareholder of Arsenal, a number of media commentators observed that the "last domino fell" with the original "Bank of England club" becoming majority owned by foreign investors.<ref>{{cite web|first=David |last=Bond |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/davidbond/2011/04/will_kroenkes_purchase_change.html |title=What does Kroenke's purchase mean for Arsenal? |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref>
===Sunderland=== The "Bank of England club" has also been used to describe [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in the late 1940s<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/columns/story/_/id/1021393/first-xi:-fa-cup-giant-killings?cc=5739# |title=First XI: FA Cup giant-killings |publisher=ESPN |date=2012-02-16 |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref> and the 1950s, where they spent large amounts of money intending to win trophies. However, the move was not successful as Sunderland failed to win any trophies during the period and were relegated in 1958.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shieldsgazette.com/sport/football/sunderland-afc/bank-of-england-club-should-be-warning-to-real-fergie-1-1245250 |title=Bank of England club should be warning to Real |publisher=Shields Gazette |date=2009-07-29 |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref>
===Everton=== [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] have also been labelled as the "Bank of England club" in 1970. This came from chairman [[John Moores (British businessman)|John Moores]] giving manager [[Harry Catterick]] large amounts of money to spend. This was successful as Everton won [[Football League First Division|the First Division]] title in 1970. However, a large exodus of players in the months afterwards meant that Everton were unable to continue as they had done in 1970.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/dna/place-lancashire/plain/A882885 |title=Everton Football Club |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
[[Category:Association football culture]] [[Category:Bank of England]] [[Category:Sports culture in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox sports competition event | competition = [[Candidates Tournament]] 2016 | governing_body = [[FIDE]] | image = Karjakin_bei_der_Schnellschach-WM_in_Berlin_2015.jpg | alt = Sergey Karjakin | caption = [[Sergey Karjakin]], the winner of the Candidates Tournament 2016, advanced to the [[World Chess Championship 2016]] match. | venue = [[Central Telegraph]] Building | location = [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] | dates = 11–30 March 2016 | competitors = 8 | nations = 6 | champion = {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Sergey Karjakin]] | win_score = 8.5 points of 14 | previous = [[Candidates Tournament 2014|2014]] | next = [[Candidates Tournament 2018|2018]] }} The '''[[Candidates Tournament]] 2016''' was an eight-player double [[round-robin tournament|round-robin]] [[chess]] tournament, held in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], from 11 to 30 March 2016. The winner, [[Sergey Karjakin]], earned the right to challenge the defending world champion, [[Magnus Carlsen]] of [[Norway]], in the [[World Chess Championship 2016]].<ref name="invite">[https://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/9200-serzh-sargsyan-is-invited-to-open-the-candidates-tournament.html Serzh Sargsyan invited to open Candidates Tournament] (FIDE News)</ref> The result was decided in the final round when Karjakin defeated runner-up [[Fabiano Caruana]].
[[FIDE]]'s commercial partner Agon was the official organizer,<ref name="fide-agon">[https://www.fide.com/images/stories/NEWS_2012/Congress/Annex_11_-_Agreement_between_FIDE_and_Agon.pdf FIDE-Agon agreement] (3.1a) of Annex 11, 2012 FIDE General Assembly</ref> with support from the Russian Chess Federation.<ref name="fide">[https://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/9179-2016-fide-world-chess-candidates-tournament.html World Chess Candidates Tournament] (FIDE)</ref> The main sponsor was the Tashir Group, a Russian real estate company headed by Armenian-born businessman [[Samvel Karapetyan (businessman)|Samvel Karapetyan]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Fischer|first=Johannes|title=Candidates will take place in March in Moscow|url=http://en.chessbase.com/post/candidates-will-take-place-in-march-in-moscow|publisher=ChessBase|accessdate=23 March 2016|date=2015-11-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=McGourty|first=Colin|title=Aronian gets wild card for Moscow Candidates|url=https://chess24.com/en/read/news/aronian-gets-wild-card-for-moscow-candidates|publisher=chess24|accessdate=23 March 2016|date=2015-11-05}}</ref>
==Organization== The tournament was contested as a double round-robin with each player playing 14 games. Four rest days took place after rounds 3, 6, 9, and 12. The winner of this 8-player candidates tournament would be the challenger of Magnus Carlsen at the 2016 World Chess Championship.<ref name="fc_2016" /> At the DI [[Central Telegraph]] Building, Agon had designed and built a 20000 square-foot space near the [[Kremlin]] to woo more spectators to the sport, with 99% of the focus on online viewership.<ref name="wsj_announcement">[https://www.wsj.com/articles/new-york-city-to-host-2016-world-chess-championship-1456796982 NYC to host 2016 WCC] by Jonathan Zalman, ''Wall Street Journal'', 1 March 2016</ref> As the official organizer, they owned live moves and video broadcasing rights.<ref>[http://www.agonlimited.com/news/2016/3/4/live-moves-and-video-from-candidates-tournament-to-be-shown-exclusively-by-worldchesscom-and-approved-broadcast-partners Live moves and video from Candidates exclusively on WorldChess ] (Agon)</ref><ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/14/kramnik-the-organizer-has-full-transmission-rights The organizer has full transmission rights ] (WorldChess)</ref> Legal actions were commenced against sites who had acted otherwise.<ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/12/official-agon-statement-on-ddos-attack-and-legal-action Official Agon statement on DDOS attack and legal action] (WorldChess)</ref>
The prize fund (Regulations 3.8.1) was 420,000 euros, with 95,000 to the winner, 88,000 to 2nd place, 75,000 to 3rd, 55,000 to 4th, 40,000 to 5th, 28,000 to 6th, 22,000 to 7th, 17,000 for 8th place. Prize money would be divided equally between players on the same score.<ref name="fc_2016" />
The FIDE supervisor was [[Zurab Azmaiparashvili]] and the chief arbiter was Werner Stubenvoll from Austria.<ref>[http://moscow2016.fide.com/officials Officials] (Moscow 2016)</ref>
==Qualifiers==
There were five different qualification paths to the Candidates Tournament.<ref name="fc_2016">{{cite web | url=http://www.fide.com/FIDE/handbook/regscandidates2016.pdf | title=Rules & regulations for the Candidates Tournament of the FIDE World Championship cycle 2014–2016 | publisher=FIDE | accessdate=17 February 2015}}</ref> In order of priority, these were: loser of the [[World Chess Championship 2014]] match, the top two finishers in the [[Chess World Cup 2015]], the top two finishers in the [[FIDE Grand Prix 2014–15]], next two highest rated players (average [[FIDE World Rankings|FIDE rating]] on the 12 monthly lists from January to December 2015, with at least 30 games played) who played in [[Chess World Cup 2015]] or [[FIDE Grand Prix 2014–15]], and one player nominated by the organizers (Agon). {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" |- ! Qualification path ! Player ! Age ! Rating ! World Ranking |- |Loser of the [[World Chess Championship 2014]] match |{{flagicon|IND}} [[Viswanathan Anand]] |46 |2762 |12 |- |rowspan="2"|The top two finishers in the [[Chess World Cup 2015]] |{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Sergey Karjakin]] |26 |2760 |13 |- |{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Peter Svidler]] |39 |2757 |16 |- |rowspan="2"|The top two finishers in the [[FIDE Grand Prix 2014–15]] |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Fabiano Caruana]] |23 |2794 |3 |- |{{flagicon|USA}} [[Hikaru Nakamura]] |28 |2790 |6 |- |rowspan="2"|The top two players with highest average 2015 rating who played in World Cup or Grand Prix |{{flagicon|BUL}} [[Veselin Topalov]] |41 |2780 |8 |- |{{flagicon|NED}} [[Anish Giri]] |21 |2793 |4 |- | [[Wild card (sports)|Wild card]] nomination of Organizers (Agon), with [[FIDE rating]] in July 2015 at least 2725 | {{flagicon|Armenia}} [[Levon Aronian]]<ref name="fide" /> |33 |2786 |7 |- |}
FIDE gave the qualifiers until January 11 to decide upon participation and sign the contract,<ref name="candidates contract">[http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/9266-2016-candidates-tournament-announcement-.html 2016 Candidates Tournament] Announcement and Contract (FIDE)</ref> and all accepted even though [[Veselin Topalov]] was open in his dislike of Moscow as a location.<ref>[http://www.newsbg.ru/sport/105-sport/13568-bolgarskij-grossmejster-nedovolen-vyborom-moskvy-dlja-provedenija-turnira-pretendentov.html Bulgarian grandmaster unhappy with choice of Moscow for the Candidates Tournament] (Russian)</ref><ref>[http://chess-news.ru/en/node/20415 Danailov Says Choosing Moscow for the Candidates is "Outrageous"] (Chess-News Russia)</ref> Topalov did not attend the opening ceremony,<ref name="chesscom round3">[https://www.chess.com/news/second-loss-for-topalov-aronian-joins-leaders-at-candidates-tournament-2992 Second Loss For Topalov, Aronian Joins Leaders At Candidates' Tournament] (Chess.Com)</ref> leaving himself open to a forfeiture of 5% of his prize money to each of FIDE and the organizers, by 3.11.2 of the Regulations.
The ratings and rankings in this table are taken from the March 2016 FIDE list. They are provided for information purposes only, and were not used for seeding. Notable highly ranked players who did not qualify include [[Vladimir Kramnik]], a former World Champion and the world number 2 as of March 2016, and [[Maxime Vachier-Lagrave]], the world number 5.<ref>[https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=393 Top 100 Players March 2015]</ref> The age column is in years as of 15 March 2016. FIDE uses a country-diversion system, so that Svidler and Karjakin, similarly Nakamura and Caruana, are paired together in rounds 1 and 8, to avoid conflicts in late rounds,<ref name="fc_2016" /> as seen in the pairings.<ref name="pairings">[http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/9421-candidates-tournament-2016-pairings.html Candidates Tournament Pairings (2016)]</ref>
===Qualifiers by rating===
The following were the final placings of players attempting to qualify by the 2015 rating lists.<ref>FIDE Top 100 lists for 2015: [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=337 January], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=341 February], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=345 March], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=349 April], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=353 May], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=357 June], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=361 July], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=365 August], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=369 September], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=373 October], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=377 November], [https://ratings.fide.com/toparc.phtml?cod=381 December]</ref>
The list omits world champion [[Magnus Carlsen]]. Players who qualified for the Candidates Tournament by other means are shown with a shaded background. The two qualifiers by rating were Topalov and Giri (marked with a green background).
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: left;" |- !Player !Jan !Feb !Mar !Apr !May !Jun !Jul !Aug !Sep !Oct !Nov !Dec !Average |- style="background:#ccffcc;" | {{flagicon|BUL}} [[Veselin Topalov]] | 2800 | 2800 | 2798 | 2798 | 2798 | 2798 | 2816 | 2816 | 2816 | 2813 | 2803 | 2803 | 2804.92 |- style="background:lightgrey;" | {{flagicon|IND}} [[Viswanathan Anand]] | 2797 | 2797 | 2791 | 2791 | 2804 | 2804 | 2816 | 2816 | 2816 | 2803 | 2803 | 2796 | 2802.83 |- style="background:lightgrey;" | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Fabiano Caruana]] | 2820 | 2811 | 2802 | 2802 | 2803 | 2805 | 2797 | 2808 | 2808 | 2796 | 2787 | 2787 | 2802.17 |-style="background:lightgrey;" | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Hikaru Nakamura]] | 2776 | 2776 | 2798 | 2798 | 2799 | 2802 | 2814 | 2814 | 2814 | 2816 | 2793 | 2793 | 2799.42 |- style="background:#ccffcc;" | {{flagicon|NED}} [[Anish Giri]] | 2784 | 2797 | 2790 | 2790 | 2776 | 2773 | 2791 | 2793 | 2793 | 2798 | 2778 | 2784 | 2787.25 |- | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Vladimir Kramnik]] | 2783 | 2783 | 2783 | 2783 | 2777 | 2783 | 2783 | 2777 | 2777 | 2777 | 2796 | 2796 | 2783.17 |- | {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Alexander Grischuk]] | 2810 | 2810 | 2794 | 2794 | 2780 | 2781 | 2771 | 2771 | 2771 | 2774 | 2750 | 2747 | 2779.42 |- style="background:lightgrey;" | {{flagicon|ARM}} [[Levon Aronian]] | 2797 | 2777 | 2770 | 2770 | 2776 | 2780 | 2765 | 2765 | 2765 | 2784 | 2781 | 2788 | 2776.50 |}

==Summary== {{Chess diagram | tright | '''Karjakin–Anand, round 4'''

{{Chess diagram | tright | '''Topalov–Karjakin, round 5'''
|rd|nd| |qd|rd| |kd| |pd| | | |bd|pd|pd|pd |bd| | | | |nd| | | | |pd|pd| | | | | | | | | | | | | |pl|nl| | |nl|pl| |pl| | |bl|pl|pl|bl|pl | |rl| |ql| |rl|kl| | Position before 13. Ne5 }}
{{Chess diagram | tright | '''Aronian–Nakamura, round 6'''
| | | | | | | | | | | |rl| |pd|kd| | | | | | | | |pd | | | | |pl|kl| | | | | | | |pl| |pl | | | | | | | | |rd| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | Position on move 74 with Black to move. Black touched his king, and so had to move it, thus allowing 75. Kf6 with decisive advantage }}
===Rounds 1–3=== The first round saw Anand beat Topalov after mutual blunders around move 20, then again around move 40, to get an early lead as all other games were drawn, two of them right at the (minimal) 30-move mark.<ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/11/candidates-results-anand-wins-three-other-games-are-draws Anand wins, three other games are draws] (WorldChess)</ref><ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/11/d%C3%A9j%C3%A0-vu-anand-takes-early-lead-at-candidates Deja Vu: Anand takes early lead] (WorldChess)</ref>
Similarly went Round 2, with two of the 3 draws occurring in 30 moves, while Nakamura missed a tactic against Karjakin and played a large unforced blunder on move 29 resulting in loss.<ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/12/karjakin-joins-anand-as-co-leader-of-candidates Karjakin joins Anand as co-leader] (WorldChess)</ref><ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/12/flash-report-karjakin-wins-after-nakamura-blunders-other-games-drawn Karjakin wins after Nakamura blunders] (WorldChess)</ref>
Round 3 saw both leaders draw, as Giri made two knight sacrifices before forcing an early draw by repetition against Karjakin, while Anand had a nagging edge against Caruana that eventually evaporated. Meanwhile, Aronian joined the leaders by beating a very off-form Topalov with Black, while Svidler as Black out-prepared Nakamura in a complicated Semi-Slav line to move 25, but failed to convert a pawn-up endgame in which [[Mark Dvoretsky]] questioned his lack of killer instinct.<ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/13/flash-report-round-3-aronian-wins-to-join-leaders-other-games-drawn Aronian wins to join leaders] (WorldChess)</ref><ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/13/three-lead-candidates-after-three-rounds Three lead after three rounds] (WorldChess)</ref>
===Rounds 4–6=== After a rest day, two of the leaders faced each other in Round 4, with Karjakin as White choosing a passive opening and coming up with an early novelty against Anand, and then saddling him with [[hanging pawns]] (''see diagram''). He then switched to a pressing endgame against Black's pawn weaknesses, and soon after the time control an Anand miscue led to his immediate resignation. This was Karjakin's first career victory over Anand at classical time controls.<ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/15/flash-report-round-4-karjakin-wins-and-is-sole-leader Karjakin Wins and is Sole Leader] (WorldChess)</ref><ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/15/karjakin-takes-charge-of-candidates Karjakin takes charge] (WorldChess)</ref>
Nakamura and Giri drew in just over an hour in 30 moves in a game that might have been completely pre-analyzed, while Svidler and Aronian drew a rook ending at the time control. The game between Caruana and Topalov saw a [[Giuoco Piano#Giuoco Pianissimo: 4.d3|Giuoco Pianissimo]] opening, before Topalov opened up the position and later blundered in time pressure, but Caruana spoiled a large advantage right after the time control by miscounting the pieces, and in the end a double rook endgame was drawn.
In Round 5, all the games were drawn, three of them at move 30 and the other at move 40.<ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/16/flash-report-all-games-are-drawn-in-round-5 All games drawn in Round 5] (WorldChess)</ref> Unlike the previous round, here when Karjakin himself had [[hanging pawns]] it did not matter (''see diagram'') and he drew comfortably.<ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/16/a-day-of-draws-leaves-karjakin-in-the-lead Day of draws leaves Karjakin in the lead ] (WorldChess)</ref>
Round 6 had Svidler losing out of opening against Anand, while Karjakin held a materially imbalanced position to a draw against Caruana. The Topalov-Giri game saw a practical novelty already at move 3, with a resulting drawn knight endgame after the 60-move mark. In the game Aronian-Nakamura, Aronian nurtured an advantage for some time, but the endgame appeared to be drawn. But on move 74, Nakamura made a [[Touch-move rule|fingerfehler]] and touched his king, forcing him to make a losing move (''see diagram''). The incident was controversial as Nakamura initially tried to claim ''[[j'adoube]]'', the international term to convey that one intends to adjust the piece, not move it.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=puRR65UUKAs Touch Move in Aronian-Nakamura ] (YouTube, WorldChess)</ref><ref>Mark Crowther, [http://theweekinchess.com/chessnews/events/fide-candidates-2016/nakamura-in-touch-move-drama-at-the-end-of-candidates-round-6 Nakamura in touch move drama at the end of Candidates Round 6], ''[[The Week in Chess]]'', 17 March 2016</ref> This win brought Aronian into the lead with Karjakin, with Anand just behind, going into the second rest day.<ref>[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/17/flash-report-rd.-6-anand-and-aronian-win-aronian-leads-with-karjakin Anand and Aronian win, Aronian leads with Karjakin] (WorldChess)</ref>
===Rounds 7–13=== {{section-stub|date=March 2018}}
===Round 14=== The tournament winner was decided in the final round game between Karjakin (playing white) and Caruana. Before this round, these were the only two players who could win the tournament, having 7.5 points each. For Caruana to win the tournament, he needed to win the game, or draw and rely on Anand to win with black against Svidler.<ref>[http://en.chessbase.com/post/candidates-r13-it-s-karjakin-or-caruana Candidates R13: It's Karjakin or Caruana!], [[Chessbase]], March 27, 2016</ref>
Caruana chose the [[Sicilian Defence]], signalling his intention to play for a win. Karjakin continued with the [[Sicilian Defence#Open Sicilian: 2.Nf3 and 3.d4|Open Sicilian]]. Caruana took the initiative and it appeared as if a win for black could be possible. His pawns were attacking the white king that had castled on the queenside. However, his own king had not castled and became a requirement for the defense of three pawns on d, e, and f file. Eventually, this weakness (aided by an imprecise move 36...Re4?) led to the collapse of the black defense. Caruana resigned on move 44, making Karjakin the winner and challenger for the World Chess Championship 2016.
==Broadcast restrictions==
In a matter that dominated early discussion of the Candidates, Agon controversially tried to claim that only approved broadcasters were able to put forth the game moves in real time.<ref name="agon exclusive">[http://www.agonlimited.com/news/2016/3/4/live-moves-and-video-from-candidates-tournament-to-be-shown-exclusively-by-worldchesscom-and-approved-broadcast-partners Moves from Candidates Tournament exclusively shown by approved broadcast partners] (Agon)</ref> However, a similar restriction was attempted by [[Sofia]] organizers first for the [[World Chess Championship 2010#Challenger Match|Topalov-Kamsky match]] in 2009 and then the [[World Chess Championship 2010]],<ref>[http://www.chessvibes.com/?q=columns/bulgarian-organizers-take-chessbase-to-court Bulgarian organizers take ChessBase to court] (ChessVibes)</ref><ref>[http://interviews.chessdom.com/chessbase-copyright-danailov ChessBase copyright, Danailov interview] (Chessdom)</ref><ref>[http://gambit.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/07/a-fight-over-relaying-chess-moves/?_r=0 A fight over relaying chess moves] Gambit Blog (NY Times)</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100605121529/http://www.dnevnik.bg/sport/2010/05/31/909514_organizatorite_na_macha_topalov_-_anand_ochakvat_pone The organizers of the match Topalov - Anand expect at least 500 thousand. Euros if ChessBase site convicted] (Bulgarian)</ref> with the end result that [[ChessBase]] was found non-culpable in a resulting lawsuit.<ref name="BCF case">[http://www.chessvibes.com/?q=reports/bulgarian-chess-federation-vs-chessbase-0-1 Bulgarian Chess Federation versus ChessBase 0-1] (ChessVibes)</ref><ref>[http://www.berlin.de/imperia/md/content/senatsverwaltungen/justiz/kammergericht/presse/16_o_270_10_urteil_vom_29.03.2010_landgericht_berlin_anonymisiert.pdf?download.html Landgericht Berlin decision 16 O 270/10] (German)</ref><ref>[http://medienrecht-blog.com/2011/04/13/uebertragungsrechte_weltmeisterschaft_schach Internet Law Blogpost] (German)</ref> The judge in that case took only half an hour to reject all demands from the Bulgarian Chess Federation (BCF), while ChessBase relied on the legal definition of a database. The most important aspect was that the judge did not agree that a chess game can be seen as a database, and therefore the BCF could not refer to their rights as database producers.<ref name="BCF case" /> The president of the BCF, [[Silvio Danailov]], estimated the loss at 1 million euros in a [[Forbes]] interview,<ref name="ECU opinion">[http://www.europechess.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/ECU-NEWSLETTER-102.pdf Danailov profile] Forbes Bulgaria, translated to English by ECU</ref> though they had only asked 15000 euros from ChessVibes for retransmission rights, and crucially only spent 8000 euros themselves, which the judge found insufficiently substantiated as a realistic amount toward a database endeavor.<ref name="BCF case" />
===Agon's legal position on move retransmission===
Agon produced a legal position white paper (Shekhovtsov & Partners), asserting that chess fans should have to agree to terms and conditions that include not re-transmitting the moves elsewhere, before being allowed access.<ref name="agon white paper">[http://www.agonlimited.com/s/white_paper_position.pdf Agon Limited, White Paper Position]</ref> This is in line with a 2011 [[European Chess Union]] memo that produced a legal opinion from Morten Sand, indicating that contract law formed a superior basis for exploiting the chess audiences, with the expectation that viewers could be made to bear 75 euros (each) for the world championships, so that "the financial upside is huge" to generate 750000 euros.<ref>[http://www.chess.sk/files/subory/1320353998ECUCommissionforCopyrightontheuseofchessgamesfromtheECUcompetitionsreport.pdf Memo Re: Copyrights of chess games – internet transmission of chess games] ECU Copyright Commission, Section 2.4</ref>
===Commentary from affected parties===
The Bulgarian website Chessdom had the strongest editorial on the matter (from CEO Anton Mihailov), calling Agon's decision a multi-level blunder, even pointing out that Agon's decision actually violates Section 4.7.3.6.4.1 of the [http://www.fide.com/FIDE/handbook/regscandidates2016.pdf Candidates Regulations] ("All live images, live broadcasting (Internet TV) pictures and all the other content for the full event details will be carried on the official domain [moscow2016.fide.com]. The organizer shall not develop any other website.").<ref name="chessdom_response">[http://www.chessdom.com/agons-new-policy-puts-the-candidates-tournament-idea-in-jeopardy Agon's new policy puts the Candidates tournament idea in jeopardy] (Chessdom)</ref> However, this item is enforceable only between Agon and [[FIDE]]. Their main thrust though, was:<blockquote>Millions of fans will not learn about this year’s Candidates matches because of AGON’s policy. Many will miss the live coverage and only learn about the games after the tournament is over, when Carlsen’s challenger is known. What is the commercial value of that? Can you calculate how much are the lost benefits for the sponsors of the event? And for the hosts? And for the players? And for the sponsors of the players?<ref name="chessdom_response" /></blockquote> Additionally, Mihailov noted the lack of equality of arms in Agon's legal salvo: "With lawyer white paper threats you have cut any journalist’s right to properly cover the Candidates. While being with the law on their side, no sane journalist will risk losing time and/or money arguing with an organization."<ref name="chessdom_response" /> Two more articles were swiftly published, including a polemic against AGON's monopolistic agenda.<ref>[http://www.chessdom.com/agons-new-controversial-policy-is-a-step-towards-monopoly/ Agon's new controversial policy is a step towards monopoly] (Chessdom)</ref> Chessdom in the end did not broadcast live moves.
[[Chess.com]] had an article on the matter, couching their Candidates preview with "a remarkable decision by the organizers might well be the biggest story here", while noting that it personally "lacks the technology [for automated PGN relay] and always relies on volunteers to bring grandmaster games in Live Chess."<ref name="chesscom_article">[https://www.chess.com/news/candidates-to-start-friday-agon-blocks-games-transmission-by-chess-sites-5161 Candidates' To Start Friday; Agon Blocks Game Transmission By Chess Sites] (Chess.com)</ref>
In the Norwegian press, [[Magnus Carlsen]] was nonchalant toward the kerfuffle, saying that everyone could just watch the Agon broadcast, with their comments and computer evaluations.<ref>[http://www.dagbladet.no/2016/03/10/sport/sjakk/magnus_carlsen/43467627 Magnus Carlsen interview] (Norwegian)</ref> However, [[NRK]] will also have move-by-move coverage on NRK.no, according to their own interview with him.<ref name="nrk mc interview">[http://www.nrk.no/sport/carlsen-fortsatt-skuffet-over-konkurrentene-1.12846681 NRK Interview with Magnus Carlsen] (Norwegian)</ref>
ChessBomb published that it would not use the Agon site due to non-agreement with terms and conditions,<ref name="chessbomb_scheme">[http://blog.chessbomb.com/2016/03/candidates-2016-to-start-with.html Candidates 2016 to start with a controversy] (ChessBomb)</ref> and asked for volunteers to seed their [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]] setup (though later dropped this initiative).<ref>[http://blog.chessbomb.com/2016/03/candidates-2016-how-to-help-us.html Candidates 2016, How to Help Us] (ChessBomb)</ref> Implicitly, this relied on the fact that the clickwrap license presented by Agon (or World Chess Events Limited) may not in fact be valid in every viewer locale, so by allowing information to be obtained and retransmitted without contractual obligation.<ref name="chessbomb_scheme" /> However, after a successful Round 1 broadcast, during Round 2 their live move transmissions were essentially halted, with looming legal threats.<ref name="tarjei_tweet" />
===Resulting effect===
[[ChessBase]] ended up taking the threats seriously, which could have been to the dismay of Agon, as the official commentators ([[Alexandra Kosteniuk]] and [[Evgeny Miroshnichenko]]) were trying to use their software in Round 1. Instead, they had to switch to manual entry from ChessBomb.<ref name="chesscom report round1">[https://www.chess.com/news/anand-beats-topalov-in-first-round-candidates-tournament-6638 Anand beats Topalov in the first round] (Chess.com)</ref> Alleged violators included not only ChessBomb and Chessdom, but also [[Internet Chess Club|ICC]], [[Chess24.com|Chess24]], and [[Der Spiegel]]. Although the Terms and Conditions (#10) mention New York state law as applicable to those who signed up, Merenzon sent a [[cease and desist]] letter that invoked 10 years [[imprisonment]] under Russian law.<ref name="chesscom report round1" /> The specifying of [[Forum selection clause|choice of venue]] and [[choice of law]] in a [[contract of adhesion]] can also be in dispute.<ref>[http://uakron.edu/dotAsset/728194.pdf Contractual choice of law in contracts of adhesion and party autonomy] by Mo Zhang, Akron Law Review, Vol. 41, 2007</ref>
Agon also impeded the credentials of Salim Fazulyanov, allegedly as retaliation against his website Kavkaz-Chess.ru for being the first Russian site to publish Chessdom's open letter.<ref name="chessdom round1">[http://www.chessdom.com/candidates-chess-2016-round-1-live Candidates Live] (Chessdom)</ref>
Eventually Agon's own worldchess.com editorial staff broke ranks, declaring that an embargo was not the way to go, but a show.<ref name="show not embargo">[http://worldchess.com/2016/03/11/win-audiences-and-sponsors-with-a-show-not-an-embargo Win Audiences and Sponsors with a Show, not an Embargo] (Agon)</ref> The main argument is: holding all the trumps like live video and exclusive interviews with players (and other VIPs) should be enough, without resorting to legal blusterings. Before Round 2, Agon partially relented, dispensing with its presumptory 2-hour [[Portable Game Notation|PGN]] embargo, designating the game's end instead.<ref>[http://www.agonlimited.com/news/2016/3/12/zvwkqafbxzlo38pzozsa310zzcvi5s Change in the timing of the release of PGN files] (Agon)</ref>
In round 1, the moves were carried live without restriction by official partner [[NRK]].<ref name="nrk mc interview" /><ref name="nrk rights">[http://www.fide.com/component/content/article/1-fide-news/9281-fide-and-agon-sign-historic-media-rights-with-nrk.html FIDE and Agon sign historic media rights with NRK] (FIDE press release)</ref><ref name="nrk access">[http://www.nrk.no/sport/sjakk NRK.no access to games]</ref> About 45 minutes into second round, the NRK live move transmission became suspended, causing other sites to also experience confusion.<ref name="nrk access" /> According to reporter Tarjei Svensen on [[Twitter]], Agon was actively pursuing lawsuits against ChessBomb, [[Chess24.com|Chess24]], [[Internet Chess Club|ICC]], and ChessGames.com,<ref name="tarjei_tweet">[https://twitter.com/TarjeiJS/status/708632720302338048 Tweet] (Tarjei Svensen)</ref> with the [[chilling effect]] of causing them to essentially suspend activity.<ref>[https://twitter.com/ChessBomb/status/708676377701183488 Tweet] (ChessBomb)</ref> The Norwegian online newspaper site VG Direkte (also an official partner) initially stayed active (with the [[browsewrap]] language: "By viewing this page you expressly agree not to publish any information concerning the chess moves of the candidates tournament 2016 chess games until the end of such game"),<ref>[http://direkte.vg.no VG Direkte game access]</ref> but then also suspended activity. [[Der Spiegel]] continued its live ticker of Aronian-Anand analysis throughout.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/sport/sonst/schach-kandidatenturnier-anand-gegen-aronjan-a-1081811.html Live Aronian-Anand Ticker Round 2] (Der Spiegel, German)</ref>
====Legal action and media coverage====
After Round 2, Agon officially announced its rumored legal action against the above four broadcasters.<ref>[http://www.agonlimited.com/news/2016/3/12/agon-ltd-commences-legal-action-against-chess24-internetchessclub-chessgames-and-chessbomb-for-breaching-broadcast-restrictions Agon Limited commences legal action] (Agon)</ref>
[[The Guardian]] newspaper covered an exposé of the ruckus,<ref name="guardian">[https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/mar/13/world-chess-champion-magnus-carlsen-candidates-tournament-moscow-agon World's chess fans await next move in battle over tournament broadcasts] by Stephen Moss (The Guardian)</ref> noting that Agon's tactics may be hoping to at least scare off its rivals and keep the big prize (coverage of the World Championship match with Carlsen) to itself.<ref>[http://www.ecforum.org.uk/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=8218&start=60#p175859 Re: Agon ban of live move transmissions] by Paolo Casaschi (English Chess Forum)</ref> [[Vladimir Kramnik]] was quoted from an ensuing interview as saying: "If you want to make chess professional, if you want to help chess to grow, you have to understand very clearly that the organiser of any chess tournament has full transmission rights. Because the organiser has invested a lot of money and effort to organise the tournament, morally and legally they have full rights over the live transmission."<ref>[http://www.agonlimited.com/news/2016/3/14/former-world-champion-vladimir-kramnik-supports-agon-over-live-broadcast-rights Kramnik supports Agon] (Agon)</ref> Kramnik contended such control was the way football, tennis and other sports had become successful, and by doing the same, chess could jump to a totally different level. He also imposed his own view upon any end user's opinion of the coverage, declaring that "no one is suffering" from Agon's decision. Top organizer [[Stuart Conquest]] was also quoted: "However you look at it, pretty clear that start of Candidates has been a PR [press relations] disaster for organisers / Agon / FIDE."<ref>[https://twitter.com/stuthefox/status/708287882738401280 Tweet] (Stuart Conquest)</ref>
====Round 3 and beyond====
ChessBomb's whole site went down (due to a component upgrade gone wrong) 10 minutes into Round 3 without any moves having been shown, while Chess24 intermittently carried the moves of two of the four games (Giri–Karjakin and Nakamura–Svidler) in the early going. Chessgames.com similarly had Giri–Karjakin, while [[Der Spiegel]] had the Anand–Caruana game on their live ticker.<ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/sport/sonst/schach-kandidatenturnier-die-dritte-runde-im-blog-a-1081816.html 3rd round live ticker] (Der Spiegel, German)</ref> After rectification 10 minutes later, ChessBomb had all three of the above-mentioned games, and Chess24 quickly added Anand–Caruana also.
By round 4 the immediate frenzy appeared to have dissipated, as Grandmaster [[David Smerdon]] was given an all-clear from Agon (or World Chess Events Limited) to run a live blog.<ref>[https://www.chess.com/blog/smurfo/live-blog---2016-world-chess-candidates-round-4 Live Blog] by David Smerdon, Candidates Round 4</ref> However, the main sites were still lagging in their relays by about 20–25 minutes during the opening moves. The (Agon affiliated) sites NRK and VG Direkte relayed the games with a delay of about 20 minutes.<ref>[https://twitter.com/TarjeiJS/status/709719598866767872 Tweet ] (Tarjei Svensen)</ref> Later, at approximately an hour into the games, the alternative feeds were nearly keeping pace with Agon's site, though some slowdown sporadically remained. Agon boasted that PGNs were now going to be available as Flash Reports within minutes of the finish of each game.<ref>[https://twitter.com/theworldchess/status/709762641896579073 Tweet ] (Agon)</ref> Their own onsite live commentators were still having problems getting the moves to the games at some junctures.<ref>[https://twitter.com/ChessVibes/status/709713144512442368 Tweet ] (ChessVibes)</ref> Renowned trainer [[Mark Dvoretsky]] was deeply unsympathetic to Agon's position, particularly as the official site was so inconvenient to use, and he also mentioned the privacy issues with the necessity of registering there.<ref name="dvoretsky">[http://chess-news.ru/node/21179 Interview, Mark Dvoretsky ] (Chess-News, Russian)</ref>
====After the tournament====
Agon, through a company called Turnir Pretendentov LLC (the name meaning 'Candidates Tournament' in Russian) attempted to sue eLearning Ltd. for 20 million roubles, for the live broadcasting of the moves of the Candidates Tournament on chess24.com. Agon's legal claim was rejected in its entirety on 25 October 2016. Agon are also suing ChessGames and ChessBomb; the final hearings in these cases are due to take place on 17 January 2017 and 28 February 2017 respectively.<ref>[https://chess24.com/en/read/news/chess24-win-moscow-case-announce-new-york-line-up chess24 win Moscow case, announce New York line-up] (chess24)</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Use Irish English|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Casement Park | nickname = '''{{lang|ga|Páirc Mhic Easmainn}}''' | coordinates = {{coord|54|34|23.93|N|5|59|2.38|W|type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | image = Roger Casement Park - geograph.org.uk - 443980.jpg | pushpin_map = United Kingdom Greater Belfast | image_size = 300px | caption = Main Stand | location = [[Belfast]], [[County Antrim]], [[Northern Ireland]] | opened = 1953 | renovated = 2000
''2014-20'' | owner = [[Antrim GAA]] | cost = | capacity = 31,661 (40,000 after redevelopment) | dimensions = 145 x 90 m | publictransit = [[Balmoral railway station]] }} [[File:Casement Park.jpg|thumb|Pitch and terracing at Casement Park]] '''Casement Park''' ({{lang-ga|Páirc Mhic Asmaint}}) is the principal [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] stadium in [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]], home to the [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]] [[Gaelic football|football]] and [[hurling]] teams. It is located in [[Andersonstown]] Road in the west of the city, and named after the [[Irish republicanism|republican]] revolutionary [[Roger Casement|Sir Roger Casement]] (1864-1916). {{As of|2015}} it had an official capacity of 32,282, with safety certification for 31,661, including 6,962 seated.{{cite web |last1=Southern |quote=Additionally, the OBC was informed by the multi-agency review of April 2009 that further informed the safety certificate revisions in 2010. That was in the context of the existing ground and a current safety certificate for circa 31,000 — there was a slight adjustment from 32,000 down to approximately 31,500 at that time. |first1=Carl |title=Inquiry into Issues around Emergency Exiting Plans, including their Impact on Stadium Capacity, for the Redeveloped Casement Park Stadium: Mr Ciarán McGurk and Mr Carl Southern |url=http://data.niassembly.gov.uk/HansardXml/committee-14495.pdf#page=13 |website=Committee for Culture, Arts and Leisure |publisher=Northern Ireland Assembly |accessdate=16 September 2018 |page=12 |date=2 July 2015}}; {{cite web |title=AQW 1178/11 |url=http://aims.niassembly.gov.uk/questions/printquestionsummary.aspx?docid=79814 |website=AIMS Portal |publisher=Northern Ireland Assembly |accessdate=16 September 2018 |date=18 October 2010}} ==History== Casement Park, one of the largest stadia in [[Ulster]], opened in June 1953, with [[Armagh Harps GFC|Armagh Harps]] defeating St John’s of [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]] in the final of the inaugural [[Ulster Senior Club Football Championship]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=If you don't like the football, there's always Celtic under the stand! |work=Gaelic Life |publisher= |date=16 May 2008 }} The newly opened Casement Park hosted the [[Ulster Senior Football Championship|Ulster Championship final]] less than a month later, which saw [[Armagh GAA|Armagh]] overcome reigning All-Ireland champions [[Cavan GAA|Cavan]]. The ground's location in a [[Physical force Irish republicanism|republican]] neighbourhood saw incidents during [[the Troubles]] which contributed to unionist perception of the GAA as pro-republican. Rallies against [[Operation Demetrius|the introduction of internment]] were held on 12 September 1971{{cite journal |title=The Past Two Weeks |jstor=25543703 |journal=Fortnight |date=1971 |issue=24 |page=16}} and 19 March 1972.{{cite journal |title=The Past Three Weeks |jstor=25544024 |journal=Fortnight |date=1972 |issue=37 |pages=11–14}} It was occupied by the [[British Army]] from [[Operation Motorman]] on 31 July 1972{{cite book |last1=Beaves |first1=Harry |title=Down Among the Weeds |date=2018 |publisher=Troubador |isbn=9781788037532 |page=73 |url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=bn5IDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA73 |language=en}} until October 1973.{{cite journal |title=The Past Two Weeks |journal=Fortnight |date=1973 |issue=69 |pages=14–15 : 15 |jstor=25544715 |subscription=Y |accessdate=16 September 2018}} [[Provisional IRA]] members displayed weapons at a rally there in August 1979.{{cite book |last1=Coogan |first1=Tim Pat |title=The IRA |date=2002 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=9780312294168 |page=444 |url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=Z4_vCgAAQBAJ&PA444 |accessdate=16 September 2018 |language=en}} In August 1988, [[Corporals killings|two Army corporals]] who drove into a republican funeral cortège were interrogated in Casement Park before being shot on nearby waste ground.{{cite web |title=Army corporals killed at IRA funeral |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/events/army_corporals_killed_at_ira_funeral |website=History - Troubles |publisher=BBC |accessdate=16 September 2018}} Anniversaries of the [[1981 Irish hunger strike|1981 hunger strike]] were marked by rallies at the stadium in 2001 and 2006, against the wishes of the [[GAA Central Council]].{{cite book |last1=Mendlowitz |first1=Andy |title=Ireland's Professional Amateurs: A Sports Season at Its Purest |date=2007 |publisher=iUniverse |isbn=9780595899869 |page=105 |url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=UcSf2l2kF3IC&pg=PA105 |accessdate=16 September 2018 |language=en}}; {{cite newspaper |newspaper=The Irish News |date=10 September 2001 |title=Mystery over 'GAA fine' for hunger strike rally at Casement}}, cited in {{cite web |title=Sectarianism And Sport In Northern Ireland |page=9: §5 "Media reports relating to sectarianism and sport" |url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/issues/sport/docs/rlsnia101001.pdf#page=12 |website=Research Paper 26/01 |publisher=Northern Ireland Assembly |accessdate=16 September 2018 |date=10 October 2001}} In all, Casement Park has hosted eight Ulster football finals. However, the Antrim ground has not held the provincial showpiece since 1971, with [[St. Tiernach's Park]] in [[Clones, County Monaghan|Clones]] hosting the final every year since except between 2004 and 2006 when it was moved to [[Croke Park]] such was the demand for tickets. A major facelift of the stadium took place in 2000, a move which saw more championship games played at Casement Park. In 2006, floodlights were added which allowed hurling and football to be played in the evening. On 14 November 2016 Casement Park was officially included as part of [[IRFU 2023 World Cup bid|Ireland's 2023 Rugby World Cup bid]], which in 2017 lost to France. ==Redevelopment== {{update section|date=September 2018}} In 2006, proposals were raised to build a new multi-purpose stadium on the site of the old [[Maze (HM Prison)|Maze prison]] near [[Lisburn]], which was intended to host [[association football]], [[rugby union]] and [[Gaelic games]]. However, opposition to the idea led to it being dropped in favour of a new venue in the [[Sydenham, Belfast|Sydenham]] area of East Belfast. This led to [[Ulster GAA]], which was one of the partners in the Maze project, to pull out in favour of remaining at Casement Park.[https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/plans-for-pound128m-belfast-stadium-unveiled-1653849.html Plans for £128m Belfast stadium unveiled] - The Independent, 25 March 2009 In 2011, the [[Northern Ireland Executive]] announced that it had granted £138m for various stadium redevelopment projects throughout Northern Ireland. Ulster GAA would receive £61.4m of this, which was to be used to redevelop Casement Park into a 40,000 all-seated stadium with £15 million of partnership investment from the Central Council of the GAA, making it the largest stadium in Ulster.[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/local/stadiums-fit-for-our-heroes-on-way-at-last-15110370.html Stadiums fit for our heroes on way at last] - Belfast Telegraph, 11 March 2011 In early 2012 it was announced that the redevelopment work would start at the end of 2013 with a view to having the new stadium open by September 2015. It was expected that, after its completion, Ulster GAA would move its headquarters from St Tiernach's Park in Clones to Casement Park,[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/northern-ireland/17074137 Ulster Council rubber-stamps Casement Park stadium move] - BBC News, 17 February 2012 which would then have a seating capacity of about 40,000.{{cite news |first=Marie Louise|last=McCrory |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Dream team for stadium redesign |work=The Irish News |publisher= |date=4 September 2012 }} In December 2014 the granting of planning permission for the redevelopment of Casement Park was ruled unlawful. On 28 April 2016 the team behind the Casement Park redevelopment proposals launched a consultation process in an effort to see what the general public's views are. ==See also== * [[List of Gaelic Athletic Association stadiums]] * [[List of stadiums in Ireland by capacity]] * [[Match for Michaela]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Antrim GAA}} {{Gaelic games venues}} [[Category:Antrim GAA]] [[Category:Gaelic games grounds in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Belfast]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1953]]

page.title: CofC Baseball Stadium at Patriots Point

revision.comment: Kithira moved page [[CofC Baseball Stadium at Patriot's Point]] to [[CofC Baseball Stadium at Patriots Point]]: correct punctuation
revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = College of Charleston Baseball Stadium at Patriot's Point | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Mount Pleasant, South Carolina|Mount Pleasant]], [[South Carolina|SC]], [[United States|USA]] | coordinates = {{coord|32.795308|-79.902159|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = 2001 | opened = 2001 | renovated = 2007 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[College of Charleston]] | operator = [[College of Charleston Cougars| Charleston Athletics]] | surface = Natural | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 2,000 | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = (L-R): 300, 375, 400, 375, 330 ft. | acreage = | tenants = [[College of Charleston Cougars| Charleston Cougars]] [[College baseball|baseball]] (2001-present)
[[Colonial Athletic Association|CAA]] Baseball Championship (2015-2016) }} '''College of Charleston Baseball Stadium at Patriots Point''' is a baseball venue located in [[Mount Pleasant, South Carolina|Mount Pleasant]], [[South Carolina]]. It is home to the [[College of Charleston Cougars]] baseball team, a member of the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Colonial Athletic Association]]. The venue is located across [[Charleston Harbor]] from the campus of the college. The field was constructed for the start of the 2001 season, adjacent to the College of Charleston soccer and softball fields. Since the ballpark opened in 2001, the Cougars have compiled a winning percentage of over .700.[http://www.cofcsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=14800&ATCLID=717502 The CofC Baseball Stadium at Patriot's Point] at cofcsports.com, URL accessed December 23, 2009. [https://web.archive.org/web/20091009153212/http://www.cofcsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=14800&ATCLID=717502 Archived] 12/23/09 ==Notable History== After the ballpark's original opening in 2001, the facility underwent a $3 million renovation in 2007 that expanded the press box to include two radio/television booths, partially covered the seating areas, and increased the seating capacity to 2,000. The site also includes locker rooms, a club house, an athletic training facility, practice field and a 4,200 square foot indoor practice facility. The ballpark saw its attendance record broken in 2012, when Charleston hosted then No. 10 [[South Carolina Gamecocks]] at Patriots Point. In May 2015, the [[Colonial Athletic Association]], of which Charleston is a member, hosted the first of two conference baseball championships at Patriots Point, the second coming in May 2016. The Patriots Point stadium is the third largest baseball facility in the CAA, behind [[Northeastern Huskies|Northeastern]] and [[UNC Wilmington Seahawks|UNCW]]. In late May 2015, the College of Charleston announced their plans to design a new athletics facility at Patriots Point. While the main addition would be a three-story athletic building adjacent to the ballpark, the plans also include the expansion of seating down the third base line at the baseball stadium. The new athletics building, which would be down the left field line of the baseball stadium, would include a weight room and sports medicine facility, locker rooms, coaches’ offices, academic spaces and a viewing deck overlooking the baseball and soccer fields.{{cite web|title=College of Charleston Announces Plans For New Athletics Facility|url=http://www.cofcsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=14800&ATCLID=210113704|website=CofCSports.com|publisher=CofCSports}} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{College of Charleston}} {{Colonial Athletic Association baseball venue navbox}} {{South Carolina NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College of Charleston Cougars baseball]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in South Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues in Charleston County, South Carolina]] [[Category:2001 establishments in South Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]] {{SouthCarolina-baseball-venue-stub}}

revision.text: {{Infobox Judo technique |name =Daki Age |image =Daki-Age.svg |image_size =175px |alt =Vector illustration of Daki age Judo throwing technique |caption =Illustration of Daki age throw |class =[[Nage-waza]] |sub_class =[[Judo_technique#Koshi-waza_.28.E8.85.B0.E6.8A.80.29:_hip_throwing_techniques|Koshi-waza]] |grip =Two hand lapel |back_up = |follow_up = |targets = |counter =[[Sweep (martial arts)|Sweep]] |kodokan =Yes |comp =No |romaji =Daki-Age |japanese =抱上 |english =High lift }}{{nihongo|'''Daki Age'''|抱上}} is a [[Throw (grappling)|throw]] in [[judo]].Mifune, Kyuzo: ''The Canon of Judo'', Kodansha International Ltd. (Tokyo) 2004, {{ISBN|4-7700-2979-9}}, p. It is one of the techniques adopted later by the Kodokan into their [[Judo Lists#Shinmeisho No Waza|Shinmeisho No Waza]] (newly accepted techniques) list. It is categorized as a hip technique, [[Judo technique|Koshi-waza]]. In practice it is very similar to a [[Body_slam|slam]], the object being for [[Tori (martial arts)|tori]] to lift [[uke (martial arts)|uke]] while in his [[Guard (grappling)|guard]] subsequently forcefully dropping uke onto their back. This is a very dangerous technique that has the potential to cause [[Spinal cord injury|spinal injuries]]. Generally uke will release their guard if they cannot prevent the lift. {{cite web | url = http://www.judoinfo.com/dakiage.htm | title = Daki Age: High Lift | author = | date = 27 February 2010 | work = throwing-techniques | publisher = © 1995/2011 JudoInfo.com | accessdate = {{date}} }} ==See also== *[[The Canon Of Judo]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * http://www.judoinfo.com/dakiage.htm www.judoinfo.com {{Judo}} {{grappling}} [[Category:Judo technique]] [[Category:Throw (grappling)]] [[Category:Grappling hold]] [[Category:Grappling positions]] [[Category:Martial art techniques]] {{Judo-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Delhi University Stadium | nickname = DU Stadium | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = University of Delhi Stadium | former_names = | location = North Campus, [[Delhi University]], India | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2008 | built = 2010 | opened = 15 July 2010 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Delhi University]] | operator = [[Delhi University]] | surface = Bermuda Princess 77 Grass – 120 m x 70 m | scoreboard = Rs, 12.87 crore | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 2,500 permanent seats
7,500 temporary | suites = 0 | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[2010 Commonwealth Games]] }} The '''Delhi University Stadium''' is a [[Rugby 7s]] [[stadium]], situated within the [[North Delhi|North]] Campus of [[Delhi University]]. Spread over {{convert|10000|sqm}}, the stadium has a [[seating capacity]] of 2,500 permanent and 7,500 temporary seats. The construction work began in 2008 and it was inaugurated in July 2010, ahead of the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]],{{cite news |title=Delhi University gets swanky new stadium |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Delhi-University-gets-swanky-new-stadium/Article1-572861.aspx |newspaper=[[Hindustan Times]] |date=15 July 2010}} and also includes training area for Netball, Boxing, Women's Wrestling and Athletics.[http://www.du.ac.in/du/index.php?page=sports-council Delhi University Sports Council] == History == After the games the stadium was handed over to the university by Commonwealth Games (CWG) Organising Committee, there after in 2011, the university initiated an extensive upgrade plan, to create a multi-purpose arena with both outdoor and indoor facilities,{{cite news |title=A guide to Delhi University facilities: All play |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-07-19/education/29790588_1_hostel-facilities-hostel-premises-girl-students |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |date= 19 July 2011}} after its completion the university students could access its facilities in late 2011.{{cite news |title=Brand new |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-01-03/news/30584325_1_du-hostels-delhi-university-foreign-universities |publisher=The Times of India |date=3 January 2012 }} The university made an extensive upgrade plan to create a multi-purpose arena with both outdoor and indoor facilities and has training area for Netball, Boxing, Women’s Wrestling and Athletics but in 2014, university decided to offer infrastructural facilities on rent to generate resources because of high maintainces.[http://www.ndtv.com/delhi-news/delhi-university-to-rent-out-premises-to-generate-resources-649703 NDTV India][http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/delhi/4-yrs-after-cwg-du-stadiums-out-of-bound-for-students/ 4 years after CWG, DU stadiums out of bound for students] ==Overview== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Features |- | Orientation – North South |- | Insulated roofing system |- | [[Rainwater harvesting]] |- | Sewerage treatment plant |- | Providing [[Variable refrigerant flow]] (VRF) system for grand stand building ([[HVAC]] system) |- |Use of ozone system (at main venue and Netball training venue’s HVAC system) to have bacteria and microbes free environment thus reducing the net tonnage of air conditioning required |- | Landscaping with plantation of trees having good dust, noise and gaseous pollutant absorbing quality |- | Use of silent type [[Engine-generator|DG]] sets using low sulphur diesel oil |- | Use of dry type transformers |- | Use of structural glazing/glass for natural light |- | Hi-tech Irrigation system for field of play having facility of collecting the water which passes through the root zone of the grass, for re-use after treatment |- | Use of recycled water for HVAC, horticulture and flushing |- | Glazing with double low E-glass |} ==Commonwealth Games Delhi,2010== Inaugurated on 15 July 2010, Delhi University Stadium hosted [[Rugby sevens at the 2010 Commonwealth Games|Rugby Sevens]] for the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]]. The stadium, spread over an area of 10,000 metres, also served as the training venue for Netball, Boxing, Women's Wrestling and Athletics during the Games. {| class="wikitable" |- | Capacity || 2,500 permanent seats
7,500 temporary |- | Competition Arena || Bermuda Princess 77 Grass – 120 m x 70 m |- |} The stadium has features like auto-sprinkling technology, underground drainage system, ozone system for air-freshening, a low power consuming air-conditioning system and natural grass.[http://www.cwgdelhi2010.org/delhi_university_0 Delhi University] 2010 Commonwealth Games website. ==Transport== The Stadium is accessible via the underground [[Vishwa Vidyalaya (Delhi Metro)|Vishwavidyalay Station]] of the [[Delhi Metro]] railway. North campus of Delhi university lies on ring road of delhi. Regular DTC bus service is available for north campus and stadium. == References == {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Delhi}} == External links == * [http://www.dukhabar.in/ Delhi University Khabar] * [http://wikimapia.org/1458190/Delhi-University-Sports-Ground Wikimapia] [[Category:Sports venues in Delhi]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]] [[Category:University of Delhi]] [[Category:2010 Commonwealth Games venues]] [[Category:Rugby union in India]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in India]] [[Category:University sports venues in India]] {{India-sports-venue-stub}}

[[Ignacio Warnes Province|Warnes]], [[Santa Cruz Department (Bolivia)|Santa Cruz]]| capacity = 9,000http://www.lostiempos.com/deportes/futbol/20160313/estadios-nacionales-ojo-tormenta | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Bolivian Football Regional Leagues]]| season = [[2010 Bolivian Football Regional Leagues|2010]]| position = | |current = 2010 Bolivian Football Regional Leagues }} '''Deortivo Warnes''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] club from [[Santa Cruz de la Sierra|Santa Cruz]], [[Bolivia]] currently playing at Santa Cruz Primera A.
